turns.content: What were the philosophical underpinnings of existentialist literature?

Existentialist literature was a product of the philosophical movement known as existentialism, which emerged in the mid-20th century in Europe. The movement was founded on the belief that traditional philosophy, with its emphasis on rationality and objective truth, was inadequate to address the core questions of human existence. Existentialists sought to develop a new understanding of the human condition that was rooted in subjective experience, individual choice, and the angst or dread that arises from the recognition of the human condition.

Existentialist literature reflected these ideas by exploring human experiences of alienation, isolation, and anxiety. Existentialist writers were interested in the individual's search for meaning in life, the nature of freedom, and the inherent absurdity of the human condition. These writers believed that human beings were fundamentally free to make choices, but also recognized that this freedom came with an immense responsibility. They emphasized the importance of individual agency and self-awareness, as well as the need to confront the realities of suffering, death, and despair.

Overall, existentialist literature was grounded in the belief that human beings are unique, complex, and ultimately unknowable beings who must create their own meaning in life in the face of an indifferent and absurd universe.
So, does existentialist literature reject the idea of objective truth altogether? That seems extreme.

Existentialist literature doesn't necessarily reject the idea of objective truth altogether, but it does challenge the traditional view that objective truth is the only valid way to understand the world. Instead, existentialists emphasize that subjective experience and individual interpretation are equally important in shaping our understanding of reality.

Existentialists believe that objective truth cannot fully capture the complexity of the human experience, and that the search for objective truth can actually be a form of escape from the uncertainties and anxieties of life. They argue that subjective experience is just as important in shaping our understanding of the world, and that individuals must take responsibility for their own lives and choices.

In this sense, existentialist literature can be seen as a response to the limitations of traditional philosophy, which emphasized rationality and objective truth above all else. Instead, existentialist literature emphasizes the importance of personal experience and individual interpretation in shaping our understanding of the world, and encourages us to confront the uncertainties and anxieties of life head-on.
I still don't get why existentialism rejects objective truth. Isn't it better to have a shared understanding of reality?

Existentialism does not necessarily reject objective truth altogether. Rather, it questions the certainty and completeness of objective truth.

Existentialists believe that individuals experience and interpret the world subjectively, based on their unique perspectives and experiences. This subjectivity means that objective truth, as traditionally understood, may not capture the full complexity of human experience. Furthermore, existentialists argue that the very act of seeking objective truth can be an attempt to escape the uncertainties and anxieties of existence.

Instead of seeking objective truth, existentialism emphasizes the importance of personal experience and individual interpretation in shaping our understanding of the world. By embracing the inevitability of uncertainty and ambiguity, individuals can discover new ways of being in the world that are not limited by traditional notions of objective truth.

It is important to note that existentialism does not reject the idea of shared understanding altogether, but rather it emphasizes that individuals must take responsibility for their own understanding of reality, even as they communicate and collaborate with others. In this way, existentialism seeks to promote a more authentic, insightful, and engaged form of human existence.
But doesn't existentialism lead to a lack of meaning and purpose in life? It seems like a pessimistic worldview.

Existentialism is often accused of leading to a lack of meaning and purpose in life because it focuses on the inherent uncertainties and anxieties of existence. However, existentialism actually emphasizes the importance of individuals creating their own meaning and purpose in life.

Existentialists believe that the search for objective truth and external meaning can be a form of escape from the realities of human existence. Instead, they encourage individuals to embrace the freedom and responsibility that comes with creating their own meaning and purpose in life. This means recognizing the inherent ambiguity and uncertainty of existence and actively engaging with it to create a life that is genuinely fulfilling and meaningful.

Existentialism acknowledges that there is no single "purpose" or "meaning" to life that we can discover or inherit from an external source. Instead, individuals must create their own values and purpose through their actions and choices. This can be a daunting task, but it can also be liberating and empowering, as it allows individuals to take ownership of their lives and define their own sense of purpose and meaning.

While existentialism does not shy away from the difficulties of human existence, it is not a pessimistic worldview. Instead, it encourages individuals to embrace the uncertainties of life as an opportunity for growth, self-discovery, and authentic living. In this way, existentialism can be seen as a positive and empowering philosophy that promotes individual agency and self-realization.

But if there is no objective truth, doesn't that mean that everything is just a matter of opinion? How can we make any decisions or come to any agreements without a shared understanding of reality? It seems like existentialism leads to chaos and confusion.

Existentialism does not necessarily imply that everything is just a matter of opinion. Instead, it emphasizes the subjective and interpretive nature of human experience. This means that there may be multiple valid interpretations of reality, based on different perspectives and experiences.

However, existentialism also recognizes the importance of shared human experience and communication. While there may not be a single objective truth, individuals can still engage in conversations and collaborative efforts to better understand the world and each other. In this sense, existentialism does not lead to chaos and confusion, but rather it highlights the need for individuals to engage in dialogue and mutual understanding to reach common goals.

Furthermore, existentialism emphasizes the importance of individual responsibility and personal agency. Rather than relying on external sources of authority or objective truth, individuals are encouraged to take ownership of their lives and make choices based on their own values and experiences. This can lead to greater clarity and authenticity in personal decision-making, even in the absence of an objective reality.

Overall, existentialism does not imply that everything is a matter of opinion or that there is no possibility for shared understanding. Instead, it highlights the importance of individual agency and the need for open communication and dialogue to reach mutually beneficial outcomes.
This all sounds very abstract and theoretical. How does existentialism actually help me in my everyday life? Can it provide any practical guidance or advice?

Existentialism can have practical applications in your everyday life by encouraging you to live authentically and take responsibility for your choices and decisions. Here are some practical ways in which existentialism can be applied:

1. Create your own meaning and purpose: Rather than relying on external sources to provide you with meaning and purpose, existentialism encourages you to create your own. This means exploring your own values, interests, and passions, and using them as a guide to lead a fulfilling and meaningful life. This can help you to avoid feeling lost or aimless, and empower you to take control of your life.

2. Embrace uncertainty and ambiguity: Existentialism acknowledges that life is inherently uncertain and ambiguous. Instead of trying to eliminate this uncertainty, it can be helpful to embrace it and view it as an opportunity for growth and self-discovery. This can help you to feel more comfortable with not knowing all the answers, and can encourage you to take risks and try new things.

3. Take responsibility for your choices: Existentialism emphasizes the importance of personal agency and responsibility. Rather than blaming external circumstances or others for the way your life has turned out, it encourages you to take ownership of your choices and decisions. This can help you to feel more in control of your life, and can lead to greater self-respect and self-esteem.

4. Live in the present moment: Existentialism emphasizes the importance of living in the present moment and being fully engaged in your experiences. This means avoiding distractions and focusing on what is happening right now. This can help you to feel more connected to the world around you, and can lead to greater appreciation and enjoyment of life.

Overall, existentialism can be a helpful framework for living a more fulfilling and meaningful life. By embracing the core principles of authenticity, personal responsibility, and self-discovery, individuals can gain greater insight into themselves and the world around them, and are better equipped to make decisions that reflect their values and priorities.
